docs.title: Kuse Cowork
docs.text:
Open-source AI Agent Framework for Desktop

A cross-platform desktop application that brings AI agent capabilities to your local machine with complete privacy control.

docs.title: What is Kuse Cowork?
docs.text:
Kuse Cowork is an open-source, cross-platform desktop application that functions as an AI agent framework. It's designed as an alternative to cloud-based AI assistants, allowing users to leverage AI agents for software development and productivity tasks with complete privacy control through BYOK (Bring Your Own Key) integration.

The agent can:

  • Read and write files in your project
  • Execute commands in isolated Docker containers
  • Search and navigate codebases
  • Access extended tools through MCP protocol
  • Plan and execute multi-step tasks autonomously

docs.title: Multi-Provider Support
docs.text: Connect to Anthropic Claude, OpenAI GPT, Google Gemini, local models (Ollama), and more. Learn more

docs.title: Autonomous Agent
docs.text: AI agent that plans and executes tasks step-by-step with real-time progress tracking. Learn more

docs.title: Secure Isolation
docs.text: Commands execute in Docker containers, keeping your system safe from unintended changes. Learn more

docs.title: Extensible Skills
docs.text: Built-in skills for PDF, DOCX, XLSX processing, with support for custom skill development. Learn more

docs.title: Commands (commands.rs)
docs.text:
Tauri command handlers that bridge frontend and backend:

#[tauri::command]
pub async fn send_chat_message(
    state: tauri::State<'_, AppState>,
    window: tauri::Window,
    conversation_id: String,
    content: String,
) -> Result<String, CommandError> {
    // Get settings
    let settings = state.db.get_settings()?;

    // Create LLM client
    let client = LLMClient::new(
        settings.api_key,
        settings.base_url,
        settings.model,
    );

    // Stream response
    let response = client.send_message_stream(
        messages,
        |chunk| {
            window.emit("chat-stream", chunk)?;
            Ok(())
        }
    ).await?;

    // Save to database
    state.db.add_message(&response)?;

    Ok(response)
}

docs.title: LLM Client (llm_client.rs)
docs.text:
Multi-provider LLM integration:

pub struct LLMClient {
    client: Client,
    api_key: String,
    base_url: String,
    model: String,
    provider_config: ProviderConfig,
}

impl LLMClient {
    pub async fn send_message_stream(
        &self,
        messages: Vec<Message>,
        on_chunk: impl Fn(String) -> Result<(), LLMError>,
    ) -> Result<String, LLMError> {
        match self.provider_config.api_format {
            ApiFormat::Anthropic => self.send_anthropic_stream(messages, on_chunk).await,
            ApiFormat::OpenAI => self.send_openai_stream(messages, on_chunk).await,
            ApiFormat::Google => self.send_google_stream(messages, on_chunk).await,
            // ...
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Agent Loop (agent/agent_loop.rs)
docs.text:
Core autonomous agent execution:

pub struct AgentLoop {
    client: Client,
    api_key: String,
    base_url: String,
    config: AgentConfig,
    tool_executor: ToolExecutor,
    message_builder: MessageBuilder,
    provider_config: ProviderConfig,
}

impl AgentLoop {
    pub async fn run_with_history(
        &mut self,
        messages: Vec<AgentMessage>,
        event_tx: mpsc::Sender<AgentEvent>,
    ) -> Result<String, String> {
        let max_turns = self.config.max_turns;

        for turn in 1..=max_turns {
            // Build API request
            let request = self.message_builder.build_request(&messages).await;

            // Send to LLM
            let response = self.send_request(&request, &event_tx).await?;

            // Parse response
            let (text, tool_uses) = self.parse_response(&response)?;

            // Execute tools if needed
            if !tool_uses.is_empty() {
                for tool_use in &tool_uses {
                    let result = self.tool_executor.execute(tool_use).await;
                    // Add result to messages...
                }
            } else {
                // No more tools, we're done
                return Ok(text);
            }
        }

        Err("Max turns exceeded".to_string())
    }
}

docs.title: Message Builder (agent/message_builder.rs)
docs.text:
Constructs API requests:

pub struct MessageBuilder {
    config: AgentConfig,
    model: String,
    max_tokens: u32,
    mcp_manager: Option<Arc<MCPManager>>,
}

impl MessageBuilder {
    pub async fn build_request(
        &self,
        messages: &[AgentMessage],
    ) -> ClaudeApiRequest {
        let mut tools = tools::get_tools(&self.config.allowed_tools);

        // Add MCP tools
        if let Some(mcp) = &self.mcp_manager {
            tools.extend(self.get_mcp_tools(mcp).await);
        }

        ClaudeApiRequest {
            model: self.model.clone(),
            max_tokens: self.max_tokens,
            system: self.config.system_prompt.clone(),
            messages: self.convert_messages(messages),
            tools,
            stream: true,
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Tool Executor (agent/tool_executor.rs)
docs.text:
Executes agent tools:

pub struct ToolExecutor {
    project_path: Option<String>,
    mcp_manager: Option<Arc<MCPManager>>,
}

impl ToolExecutor {
    pub async fn execute(&self, tool_use: &ToolUse) -> ToolResult {
        // Check for MCP tools
        if tool_use.name.starts_with("mcp_") {
            return self.execute_mcp_tool(tool_use).await;
        }

        // Execute built-in tools
        match tool_use.name.as_str() {
            "read_file" => tools::read_file(tool_use),
            "write_file" => tools::write_file(tool_use),
            "edit_file" => tools::edit_file(tool_use),
            "bash" => tools::bash(tool_use, &self.project_path).await,
            "glob" => tools::glob(tool_use, &self.project_path),
            "grep" => tools::grep(tool_use, &self.project_path),
            "list_dir" => tools::list_dir(tool_use),
            "docker_run" => tools::docker_run(tool_use, &self.project_path),
            _ => ToolResult::error(tool_use.id.clone(), "Unknown tool"),
        }
    }
}

docs.title: File Operations
docs.text:
// tools/file_read.rs
pub fn read_file(tool_use: &ToolUse) -> ToolResult {
    let path = tool_use.input.get("path")
        .and_then(|v| v.as_str())
        .ok_or("Missing path")?;

    // Expand ~ to home directory
    let expanded = expand_tilde(path);

    let content = std::fs::read_to_string(&expanded)?;

    ToolResult::success(tool_use.id.clone(), content)
}

docs.title: Docker Integration
docs.text:
// tools/docker.rs
pub async fn docker_run(
    tool_use: &ToolUse,
    project_path: &Option<String>,
) -> ToolResult {
    let docker = Docker::connect_with_local_defaults()?;

    let image = tool_use.input.get("image")
        .and_then(|v| v.as_str())
        .unwrap_or("python:3.11-alpine");

    let command = tool_use.input.get("command")
        .and_then(|v| v.as_str())
        .ok_or("Missing command")?;

    // Create container config
    let config = Config {
        image: Some(image),
        cmd: Some(vec!["/bin/sh", "-c", command]),
        host_config: Some(HostConfig {
            binds: Some(vec![
                format!("{}:/workspace", project_path),
                format!("{}:/skills:ro", skills_path),
            ]),
            ..Default::default()
        }),
        ..Default::default()
    };

    // Create and run container
    let container = docker.create_container(None, config).await?;
    docker.start_container(&container.id, None).await?;

    // Wait and get output
    let output = docker.wait_container(&container.id).await?;
    let logs = docker.logs(&container.id, options).await?;

    // Cleanup
    docker.remove_container(&container.id, None).await?;

    ToolResult::success(tool_use.id.clone(), logs)
}

docs.title: MCP Manager (mcp/client.rs)
docs.text:
pub struct MCPManager {
    servers: RwLock<HashMap<String, MCPServer>>,
    http_client: Client,
}

impl MCPManager {
    pub async fn add_server(&self, config: MCPServerConfig) -> Result<(), MCPError> {
        let server = MCPServer::connect(config).await?;
        self.servers.write().await.insert(server.id.clone(), server);
        Ok(())
    }

    pub async fn get_all_tools(&self) -> Vec<MCPTool> {
        let servers = self.servers.read().await;
        let mut tools = Vec::new();

        for server in servers.values() {
            if server.is_connected() {
                tools.extend(server.tools.clone());
            }
        }

        tools
    }

    pub async fn execute_tool(&self, call: &MCPToolCall) -> Result<String, MCPError> {
        let servers = self.servers.read().await;
        let server = servers.get(&call.server_id)
            .ok_or(MCPError::ServerNotFound)?;

        server.call_tool(&call.tool_name, &call.parameters).await
    }
}

docs.title: Error Types
docs.text:
#[derive(Error, Debug)]
pub enum LLMError {
    #[error("HTTP error: {0}")]
    Http(#[from] reqwest::Error),

    #[error("API error: {0}")]
    Api(String),

    #[error("Parse error: {0}")]
    Parse(String),

    #[error("Unsupported provider: {0}")]
    UnsupportedProvider(String),
}

#[derive(Debug, Serialize)]
pub struct CommandError {
    pub message: String,
}

impl From<LLMError> for CommandError {
    fn from(err: LLMError) -> Self {
        CommandError {
            message: err.to_string(),
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Streaming with Channels
docs.text:
use tokio::sync::mpsc;

pub async fn run_agent_with_events(
    request: AgentRequest,
    window: Window,
) -> Result<String, CommandError> {
    let (tx, mut rx) = mpsc::channel(100);

    // Spawn event forwarder
    let event_window = window.clone();
    tokio::spawn(async move {
        while let Some(event) = rx.recv().await {
            let _ = event_window.emit("agent-event", event);
        }
    });

    // Run agent
    let result = agent_loop.run_with_history(messages, tx).await;

    Ok(result?)
}

docs.title: Input Validation
docs.text:
fn validate_path(path: &str) -> Result<PathBuf, ToolError> {
    let expanded = expand_tilde(path);
    let canonical = expanded.canonicalize()?;

    // Prevent path traversal
    if !canonical.starts_with(&project_root) {
        return Err(ToolError::AccessDenied);
    }

    Ok(canonical)
}

docs.title: Command Sanitization
docs.text:
// Commands run in Docker are isolated
// But we still validate inputs
fn sanitize_command(cmd: &str) -> Result<String, ToolError> {
    if cmd.contains("rm -rf /") || cmd.contains(":(){ :|:& };:") {
        return Err(ToolError::DangerousCommand);
    }
    Ok(cmd.to_string())
}

docs.title: App Component
docs.text:
The root component that handles routing and layout:

const App: Component = () => {
  const [view, setView] = createSignal<'chat' | 'tasks'>('chat');

  return (
    <div class="app">
      <Sidebar view={view()} onViewChange={setView} />
      <main>
        <Switch>
          <Match when={view() === 'chat'}>
            <Chat />
          </Match>
          <Match when={view() === 'tasks'}>
            <AgentMain />
          </Match>
        </Switch>
      </main>
      <Show when={showSettings()}>
        <Settings />
      </Show>
    </div>
  );
};

const Chat: Component = () => {
  const [messages, setMessages] = createSignal<Message[]>([]);
  const [input, setInput] = createSignal('');
  const [streaming, setStreaming] = createSignal(false);

  const sendMessage = async () => {
    const content = input();
    setInput('');

    await sendChatMessage(conversationId, content, (text) => {
      // Update streaming display
    });

  return (
    <div class="chat">

docs.title: Settings Store
docs.text:
Global settings management:

// stores/settings.ts
import { createSignal } from "solid-js";

export interface Settings {
  apiKey: string;
  model: string;
  baseUrl: string;
  maxTokens: number;
  temperature?: number;
  providerKeys: Record<string, string>;
}

const [settings, setSettings] = createSignal<Settings>(DEFAULT_SETTINGS);

export function useSettings() {
  return {
    settings,
    updateSetting: async <K extends keyof Settings>(
      key: K,
      value: Settings[K]
    ) => {
      const newSettings = { ...settings(), [key]: value };
      setSettings(newSettings);
      await persistSettings(newSettings);
    },
  };
}

Message history and conversation state:

// stores/chat.ts
import { createStore } from "solid-js/store";

export interface Message {
  id: string;
  role: "user" | "assistant";
  content: string;
  timestamp: number;
}

const [messages, setMessages] = createStore<Message[]>([]);

export function useChat() {
  return {
    messages,
    addMessage: (msg: Message) => {
      setMessages(m => [...m, msg]);
    },
    clearMessages: () => {
      setMessages([]);
    },
  };
}

docs.title: API Bridge
docs.text:
Communication with the Rust backend:

// lib/tauri-api.ts
import { invoke } from "@tauri-apps/api/core";
import { listen, UnlistenFn } from "@tauri-apps/api/event";

export async function sendChatMessage(
  conversationId: string,
  content: string,
  onStream: (text: string) => void
): Promise<string> {
  let unlisten: UnlistenFn | undefined;

  try {
    unlisten = await listen<StreamPayload>("chat-stream", (event) => {
      onStream(event.payload.text);
    });

    return await invoke<string>("send_chat_message", {
      conversationId,
      content,
    });
  } finally {
    unlisten?.();
  }
}

docs.title: Event Handling
docs.text:
Real-time updates from backend:

// Listening for agent events
const unlisten = await listen<AgentEvent>("agent-event", (event) => {
  switch (event.payload.type) {
    case "text":
      updateContent(event.payload.content);
      break;
    case "tool_start":
      showToolExecution(event.payload.tool);
      break;
    case "tool_end":
      hideToolExecution();
      break;
    case "done":
      completeTask();
      break;
  }
});

docs.title: Web Fallback
docs.text:
For development without Tauri:

// lib/tauri-api.ts
export function isTauri(): boolean {
  return typeof window !== "undefined" &&
    ("__TAURI__" in window || "__TAURI_INTERNALS__" in window);
}

export async function getSettings(): Promise<Settings> {
  if (!isTauri()) {
    // Fallback to localStorage
    const stored = localStorage.getItem("kuse-cowork-settings");
    return stored ? JSON.parse(stored) : DEFAULT_SETTINGS;
  }
  return invoke<Settings>("get_settings");
}

docs.title: AI Client (Web Mode)
docs.text:
Direct AI provider access for web development:

// lib/ai-client.ts
class AnthropicProvider implements AIProvider {
  async sendMessage(
    messages: AIMessage[],
    settings: Settings,
    onStream?: (text: string) => void
  ): Promise<string> {
    const response = await fetch(`${settings.baseUrl}/v1/messages`, {
      method: "POST",
      headers: {
        "x-api-key": settings.apiKey,
        "anthropic-version": "2023-06-01",
      },
      body: JSON.stringify({
        model: settings.model,
        messages,
        stream: !!onStream,
      }),
    });

    if (onStream) {
      return this.handleStreamResponse(response, onStream);
    }
    return this.handleResponse(response);
  }
}

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text: Kuse Cowork is built as a desktop application using modern technologies for both frontend and backend.

docs.title: High-Level Architecture
docs.text:
graph TB
    subgraph User["User Layer"]
        UI[Desktop UI]
    end

    subgraph Frontend["Frontend (SolidJS)"]
        Components[UI Components]
        Stores[State Stores]
        API[Tauri API Bridge]
    end

    subgraph Backend["Backend (Rust/Tauri)"]
        Commands[Tauri Commands]
        AgentLoop[Agent Loop]
        LLMClient[LLM Client]
        ToolExec[Tool Executors]
        MCPMgr[MCP Manager]
        DB[(SQLite)]
    end

    subgraph External["External Services"]
        AI[AI Providers]
        Docker[Docker Engine]
        MCP[MCP Servers]
    end

    UI --> Components
    Components --> Stores
    Components --> API
    API --> Commands
    Commands --> AgentLoop
    AgentLoop --> LLMClient
    AgentLoop --> ToolExec
    AgentLoop --> MCPMgr
    Commands --> DB
    LLMClient --> AI
    ToolExec --> Docker
    MCPMgr --> MCP

docs.title: Frontend
docs.text: Technology Purpose SolidJS Reactive UI framework TypeScript Type safety Vite Build tool CSS Modules Styling

docs.title: Backend
docs.text: Technology Purpose Rust Systems programming Tauri 2.0 Desktop framework Tokio Async runtime SQLite Local database Reqwest HTTP client Bollard Docker API

docs.title: Communication
docs.text: Layer Method Frontend ↔ Backend Tauri IPC (invoke/events) Backend ↔ AI HTTP/HTTPS (REST/SSE) Backend ↔ Docker Docker API Backend ↔ MCP HTTP/Stdio

docs.title: Frontend Components
docs.text:
src/
├── App.tsx              # Main app shell
├── components/
│   ├── Chat.tsx         # Chat interface
│   ├── AgentMain.tsx    # Agent execution view
│   ├── TaskPanel.tsx    # Task progress display

│   └── MCPSettings.tsx  # MCP configuration
├── stores/
│   ├── settings.ts      # Settings state
│   └── chat.ts          # Chat state
└── lib/
    ├── tauri-api.ts     # Backend bridge
    ├── ai-client.ts     # Direct AI access
    └── mcp-api.ts       # MCP client

docs.text:
src-tauri/src/
├── main.rs              # Application entry
├── lib.rs               # Library root

│   ├── message_builder.rs # Request construction

docs.title: Chat Message Flow
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant UI
    participant Store
    participant TauriAPI
    participant Commands
    participant LLMClient
    participant AI

    User->>UI: Type message
    UI->>TauriAPI: send_chat_message
    TauriAPI->>Commands: invoke
    Commands->>LLMClient: send_message_stream
    LLMClient->>AI: HTTP POST (streaming)
    AI-->>LLMClient: SSE chunks
    LLMClient-->>Commands: Process chunks
    Commands-->>TauriAPI: emit events
    TauriAPI-->>UI: update display
    UI-->>User: Show response

docs.title: Agent Task Flow
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant UI
    participant Commands
    participant AgentLoop
    participant Tools
    participant Docker

    User->>UI: Create task
    UI->>Commands: run_task_agent
    Commands->>AgentLoop: run_with_history
    loop Each turn
        AgentLoop->>AgentLoop: Send to LLM
        AgentLoop->>AgentLoop: Parse response
        alt Tool needed
            AgentLoop->>Tools: execute
            Tools->>Docker: run container
            Docker-->>Tools: output
            Tools-->>AgentLoop: result
        end
        AgentLoop-->>Commands: emit event
        Commands-->>UI: update display
    end
    AgentLoop-->>Commands: complete
    Commands-->>UI: show result

docs.title: Frontend State
docs.text:
State is managed using SolidJS signals and stores:

// Settings store
const [settings, setSettings] = createSignal<Settings>(DEFAULT_SETTINGS);

// Chat store
const [messages, setMessages] = createStore<Message[]>([]);

docs.title: Backend State
docs.text:
State is persisted in SQLite:

-- Settings table
CREATE TABLE settings (
    key TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
    value TEXT
);

-- Conversations table
CREATE TABLE conversations (
    id TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
    title TEXT,
    created_at INTEGER,
    updated_at INTEGER
);

-- Messages table
CREATE TABLE messages (
    id TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
    conversation_id TEXT,
    role TEXT,
    content TEXT,
    timestamp INTEGER
);

docs.title: Tauri Events
docs.text:
Events flow from backend to frontend:

// Backend: Emit event
window.emit("chat-event", ChatEvent::Text { content })?;

// Frontend: Listen for event
await listen<ChatEvent>("chat-event", (event) => {
    onEvent(event.payload);
});

docs.title: Event Types
docs.text: Event Direction Purpose chat-stream Backend → Frontend Streaming chat response chat-event Backend → Frontend Tool execution events agent-event Backend → Frontend Agent progress updates

docs.title: Data Protection
docs.text:
• Local Storage: All data in local SQLite
  • No Telemetry: No external data transmission
  • API Keys: Stored locally, passed only to providers
  • Container Isolation: Commands run in Docker

docs.title: Streaming
docs.text:
• SSE for real-time responses
  • Incremental UI updates
  • Token-by-token display

docs.title: Caching
docs.text:
• Model configurations cached
  • Connection states maintained
  • Context reused across turns

docs.title: Resource Management
docs.text:
• Container cleanup after execution
  • Connection pooling for HTTP
  • Memory-efficient file handling

docs.title: Adding Providers
docs.text:
1. Implement in llm_client.rs
  2. Add format detection
  3. Handle authentication
  4. Support streaming

docs.title: Adding Tools
docs.text:
1. Create in tools/ directory
  2. Register in tools/mod.rs
  3. Add to agent config
  4. Handle in tool executor

docs.title: Adding MCP Servers
docs.text:
1. Define server config
  2. Implement tool discovery
  3. Handle authentication
  4. Process tool calls

docs.title: Building
docs.text: This guide covers building Kuse Cowork for distribution.

docs.title: Build Requirements
docs.text: Ensure you have all prerequisites from Development Setup.

docs.title: Development Build
docs.text:
# Quick development build
pnpm tauri build --debug

Output: src-tauri/target/debug/

docs.title: Local Build
docs.text:
# Full production build
pnpm tauri build

Output locations: - macOS: src-tauri/target/release/bundle/dmg/ - Windows: src-tauri/target/release/bundle/msi/ - Linux: src-tauri/target/release/bundle/deb/

docs.title: Platform-Specific Builds
docs.text:
macOSWindowsLinux 
# Build for current architecture
pnpm tauri build

# Build for specific architecture
pnpm tauri build --target aarch64-apple-darwin  # Apple Silicon
pnpm tauri build --target x86_64-apple-darwin   # Intel

# Universal binary (both architectures)
pnpm tauri build --target universal-apple-darwin

Output formats: - .app - Application bundle - .dmg - Disk image - .pkg - Installer package

# Build for Windows
pnpm tauri build

# Build specific format
pnpm tauri build --bundles msi
pnpm tauri build --bundles nsis

Output formats: - .exe - Executable - .msi - MSI installer - *-setup.exe - NSIS installer

# Build for Linux
pnpm tauri build

# Build specific format
pnpm tauri build --bundles deb
pnpm tauri build --bundles appimage
pnpm tauri build --bundles rpm

Output formats: - .deb - Debian package - .rpm - Red Hat package - .AppImage - Universal Linux app

docs.title: From macOS

brew install mingw-w64
rustup target add x86_64-pc-windows-gnu

sudo apt install mingw-w64

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text:
.github/workflows/build.yml:

name: Build

on:
  push:
    tags:
      - 'v*'

jobs:
  build:
    strategy:
      matrix:
        include:
          - os: macos-latest
            target: aarch64-apple-darwin
          - os: macos-latest
            target: x86_64-apple-darwin
          - os: windows-latest
            target: x86_64-pc-windows-msvc
          - os: ubuntu-latest
            target: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu

    runs-on: ${{ matrix.os }}

    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Setup Node
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 20

      - name: Setup pnpm
        uses: pnpm/action-setup@v2
        with:
          version: 8

      - name: Install Rust
        uses: dtolnay/rust-action@stable
        with:
          targets: ${{ matrix.target }}

      - name: Install dependencies (Linux)
        if: matrix.os == 'ubuntu-latest'
        run: |
          sudo apt-get update
          sudo apt-get install -y libwebkit2gtk-4.1-dev libayatana-appindicator3-dev

      - name: Install frontend dependencies
        run: pnpm install

      - name: Build
        run: pnpm tauri build --target ${{ matrix.target }}

      - name: Upload artifacts
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
        with:
          name: binaries-${{ matrix.target }}
          path: src-tauri/target/${{ matrix.target }}/release/bundle/

docs.title: macOS
docs.text:
1. Get Apple Developer certificate
  2. Export certificate to .p12
  3. Set environment variables:
export APPLE_CERTIFICATE="base64-encoded-p12"
export APPLE_CERTIFICATE_PASSWORD="password"
export APPLE_SIGNING_IDENTITY="Developer ID Application: ..."
  1. Build with signing:
pnpm tauri build

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
1. Get code signing certificate (EV recommended)
  2. Configure in tauri.conf.json:
{
  "bundle": {
    "windows": {
      "certificateThumbprint": "YOUR_THUMBPRINT",
      "digestAlgorithm": "sha256"
    }
  }
}

docs.title: macOS Notarization
docs.text:
1. Configure Apple credentials:
export APPLE_ID="your@email.com"
export APPLE_PASSWORD="app-specific-password"
export APPLE_TEAM_ID="TEAM_ID"
  1. Enable in config:
{
  "bundle": {
    "macOS": {
      "entitlements": "entitlements.plist",
      "signingIdentity": "-"
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Minimize Binary Size
docs.text:
# Cargo.toml
[profile.release]
lto = true           # Link-time optimization
opt-level = "s"      # Optimize for size
strip = true         # Strip symbols
codegen-units = 1    # Better optimization

docs.title: Faster Builds
docs.text:
# For development
[profile.dev]
opt-level = 0
debug = true

# For CI
[profile.release]
lto = "thin"         # Faster than full LTO
codegen-units = 16   # Faster compilation

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Build fails with missing libraries

Linux: 

sudo apt install libwebkit2gtk-4.1-dev libayatana-appindicator3-dev

macOS: 

xcode-select --install

Code signing fails
  1. Verify certificate is valid
  2. Check keychain access
  3. Ensure correct identity name
Build is too large
  1. Enable LTO in release profile
  2. Use opt-level = "s" or "z"
  3. Strip debug symbols
Cross-compilation fails
  1. Install target: rustup target add <target>
  2. Install cross-compiler toolchain
  3. Check linker configuration

docs.title: Versioning
docs.text:
Update version in multiple places:

  1. package.json: 

    { "version": "1.0.0" }

  2. src-tauri/Cargo.toml: 

    version = "1.0.0"

  3. src-tauri/tauri.conf.json: 

    { "version": "1.0.0" }

docs.title: Contributing Guide
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to Kuse Cowork! This guide will help you get started.

docs.title: Ways to Contribute
docs.text:
• Bug Reports: Report issues you encounter
  • Feature Requests: Suggest new features
  • Code: Submit pull requests
  • Documentation: Improve docs
  • Testing: Help test new releases
  • Community: Help others in discussions

docs.title: 1. Fork the Repository
docs.text:
1. Go to github.com/kuse-ai/kuse_cowork
  2. Click "Fork"
  3. Clone your fork:
git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/kuse_cowork.git
cd kuse_cowork

docs.title: 2. Set Up Development Environment
docs.text: Follow the Development Setup guide.

docs.title: 3. Create a Branch
docs.text:
# Create feature branch
git checkout -b feature/my-feature

# Or bugfix branch
git checkout -b fix/issue-123

docs.title: Making Changes
docs.text:
1. Make your changes
  2. Test locally with pnpm tauri dev
  3. Run linters and tests
# Frontend
pnpm lint
pnpm test

# Backend
cd src-tauri
cargo fmt
cargo clippy
cargo test

docs.title: Commit Messages
docs.text:
Follow conventional commits:

type(scope): description

[optional body]

[optional footer]

Types: - feat: New feature - fix: Bug fix - docs: Documentation - style: Formatting - refactor: Code restructuring - test: Adding tests - chore: Maintenance

Examples:

feat(agent): add support for parallel tool execution

fix(docker): handle container cleanup on timeout

docs(readme): update installation instructions

docs.title: Pull Request Process
docs.text:
1. Push your branch: 

    git push origin feature/my-feature

  2. Create Pull Request:

  3. Go to your fork on GitHub
  4. Click "Compare & pull request"

  5. Fill out the PR template

  6. PR Template: 

    ## Description
Brief description of changes

## Type of Change
- [ ] Bug fix
- [ ] New feature
- [ ] Documentation
- [ ] Refactoring

## Testing
How was this tested?

## Checklist
- [ ] Code follows style guidelines
- [ ] Tests pass locally
- [ ] Documentation updated

  7. Review Process:

  8. Maintainers will review your PR
  9. Address feedback
  10. Once approved, PR will be merged

docs.title: TypeScript/SolidJS
docs.text:
// Use TypeScript types
interface Props {
  title: string;
  onClick: () => void;
}

// Functional components
const MyComponent: Component<Props> = (props) => {
  // Use signals for state
  const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0);

  // Use createMemo for derived state
  const doubled = createMemo(() => count() * 2);

  return (
    <div>
      <h1>{props.title}</h1>
      <button onClick={props.onClick}>
        Count: {count()} (doubled: {doubled()})
      </button>
    </div>
  );
};

docs.title: Development Setup
docs.text: This guide covers setting up a development environment for contributing to Kuse Cowork.

docs.title: Required Tools
docs.text: Tool Version Purpose Node.js 18+ Frontend runtime pnpm 8+ Package manager Rust 1.70+ Backend language Docker 20+ Container runtime

docs.title: Platform-Specific Setup
docs.text:
macOSWindowsLinux (Ubuntu/Debian) 
# Install Homebrew
/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"

# Install dependencies
brew install node pnpm rust

# Install Tauri CLI
cargo install tauri-cli

# Install Docker Desktop
brew install --cask docker
  1. Install Node.js (LTS version)
  2. Install pnpm: npm install -g pnpm
  3. Install Rust
  4. Install Visual Studio Build Tools with C++ workload
  5. Install Docker Desktop
  6. Install Tauri CLI: cargo install tauri-cli
# Install system dependencies
sudo apt update
sudo apt install -y \
    libwebkit2gtk-4.1-dev \
    build-essential \
    curl \
    wget \
    libssl-dev \
    libgtk-3-dev \
    libayatana-appindicator3-dev \
    librsvg2-dev

# Install Node.js
curl -fsSL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_20.x | sudo -E bash -
sudo apt install -y nodejs

# Install pnpm
npm install -g pnpm

# Install Rust
curl --proto '=https' --tlsv1.2 -sSf https://sh.rustup.rs | sh
source $HOME/.cargo/env

# Install Tauri CLI
cargo install tauri-cli

# Install Docker
curl -fsSL https://get.docker.com -o get-docker.sh
sudo sh get-docker.sh
sudo usermod -aG docker $USER

docs.title: Clone and Setup
docs.text:
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/kuse-ai/kuse_cowork.git
cd kuse_cowork

# Install frontend dependencies
pnpm install

# Verify Rust setup
cd src-tauri
cargo check
cd ..

docs.title: Start Development Server
docs.text:
# Start with hot reload
pnpm tauri dev

This will: 1. Start the Vite dev server (port 1420) 2. Compile the Rust backend 3. Launch the application with DevTools

For faster iteration on UI changes:

pnpm dev

Access at http://localhost:1420

Web Mode Limitations

Without Tauri, some features are unavailable: - Tool execution - Docker integration - MCP connections - Local file access

// Good

  const [state, setState] = createSignal(0);

};

docs.title: Agent System
docs.text: The Kuse Cowork agent is an autonomous AI system that can plan and execute complex tasks using a combination of language models and tools.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[User Request] --> B[Agent Loop]
    B --> C{Create Plan}
    C --> D[Execute Step]
    D --> E{Tool Needed?}
    E -->|Yes| F[Execute Tool]
    E -->|No| G[Generate Response]
    F --> H[Process Result]
    H --> D
    G --> I{Task Complete?}
    I -->|No| D
    I -->|Yes| J[Final Response]

docs.title: Agent Loop
docs.text:
The agent operates in a loop, processing the task step by step:

  1. Receive Request: User provides task description and optional project context
  2. Create Plan: Agent analyzes the request and creates a step-by-step plan
  3. Execute Steps: Each step is executed, potentially using tools
  4. Track Progress: Status events are emitted in real-time
  5. Complete: Final response is generated and saved

docs.title: Maximum Turns
docs.text: The agent has a configurable maximum number of turns (default: 20). Each API call counts as one turn. This prevents infinite loops and runaway costs.

docs.title: Planning
docs.text:
When given a task, the agent first creates a structured plan:

<plan>
1. Read the existing code file
2. Analyze the current implementation
3. Identify areas for improvement
4. Make the necessary edits
5. Verify the changes work
</plan>

docs.title: Plan Visualization
docs.text:
The UI shows:

  • Step Number: Current step being executed
  • Description: What the step aims to accomplish
  • Status: Pending, In Progress, Completed, or Failed
  • Progress Markers: [STEP 1 START] and [STEP 1 DONE]

docs.title: Tool Execution
docs.text: The agent can use various tools to accomplish tasks:

docs.title: Available Tools
docs.text: Tool Description Example Use read_file Read file contents Understanding existing code write_file Create or overwrite files Creating new files edit_file Make targeted edits Modifying existing code bash Run shell commands Building, testing, git operations glob Find files by pattern Locating files in a project grep Search file contents Finding code patterns list_dir List directory contents Exploring project structure docker_run Run Docker containers Isolated command execution

docs.title: Tool Selection
docs.text:
The agent automatically selects appropriate tools based on the task:

  • Reading code? → read_file, glob, grep
  • Making changes? → edit_file, write_file
  • Running commands? → bash, docker_run
  • Exploring project? → list_dir, glob

docs.title: Real-time Events
docs.text: The agent emits events during execution:

docs.title: Event Types
docs.text: Event Description text Text content from the agent plan Plan has been created step_start Step execution started step_done Step execution completed tool_start Tool is being executed tool_end Tool execution finished turn_complete API turn completed done Task is complete error An error occurred

docs.title: Event Flow Example
docs.text:
[text] I'll help you refactor this code...
[plan] Created 5-step plan
[step_start] Step 1
[tool_start] read_file: src/component.tsx
[tool_end] success
[step_done] Step 1
[step_start] Step 2
[tool_start] edit_file: src/component.tsx
[tool_end] success
[step_done] Step 2
...
[done] Completed in 8 turns

docs.title: Project Context
docs.text:
When a project folder is selected:

  • Files are accessible via tools
  • Folder is mounted at /workspace in Docker
  • Agent understands project structure

docs.title: Conversation History
docs.text:
The agent maintains context across turns:

  • Previous messages are included in prompts
  • Tool results are part of the conversation
  • Context helps with follow-up tasks

docs.title: Token Management
docs.text:
Long conversations are managed through:

  • Context truncation for large files
  • Summarization of verbose outputs
  • Smart selection of relevant history

docs.title: Simple Tasks
docs.text:
Quick, single-step operations:

"What's in the package.json file?"

Agent: Reads file, provides summary

docs.title: Multi-step Tasks
docs.text:
Complex operations requiring planning:

"Add a dark mode toggle to the settings page"

Agent: 1. Read existing settings component 2. Analyze current styling approach 3. Create theme context/store 4. Add toggle component 5. Update styles 6. Test the implementation

docs.title: Iterative Tasks
docs.text:
Tasks requiring back-and-forth:

"Let's debug why the tests are failing"

Agent: 1. Run tests to see failures 2. Read failing test files 3. Read related source code 4. Identify issues 5. Propose fixes 6. Apply fixes 7. Re-run tests 8. Repeat if needed

docs.title: Graceful Degradation
docs.text:
When tools fail, the agent:

  1. Reports the error
  2. Attempts alternative approaches
  3. Asks for user guidance if stuck

docs.title: Common Errors
docs.text: Error Cause Resolution File not found Wrong path Check file exists, use glob Permission denied Access issue Check permissions Docker error Container issue Verify Docker is running API error Provider issue Check API key, rate limits

docs.title: Recovery Strategies
docs.text:
• Retry with different approach: Try alternative tools or methods
  • Ask for clarification: Request more specific instructions
  • Report partial progress: Show what was accomplished before error

docs.title: Writing Effective Prompts
docs.text:
Be Specific

❌ "Fix the bug" ✅ "Fix the TypeError in handleSubmit function in src/components/Form.tsx"

Provide Context

❌ "Add authentication" ✅ "Add JWT authentication to the /api/users endpoint using the existing auth middleware"

Break Down Complex Tasks

❌ "Build a complete e-commerce site" ✅ "Create the product listing component with filtering"

docs.title: Optimizing Performance
docs.text:
• Select project folder: Enables faster file access
  • Use tool mode: Enable tools for actionable tasks
  • Provide file paths: Direct paths are faster than searching

docs.title: Working with Large Projects
docs.text:
• Focus on specific directories or files
  • Use glob patterns to narrow scope
  • Break large refactors into smaller tasks

docs.title: System Prompt
docs.text:
The agent uses a system prompt that defines its behavior:

You are Kuse Cowork, an AI agent that helps users with
software development tasks.

## IMPORTANT: Always Create a Plan First

Before starting ANY task, you MUST output a plan in this
exact format:

<plan>
1. [First step description]
2. [Second step description]
...
</plan>

## Guidelines
- Always read files before modifying them
- Use edit_file for small changes, write_file for new files
- Be careful with bash commands
- Search with glob and grep before making assumptions

docs.title: Customization
docs.text:
Future versions may support custom system prompts for:

  • Different coding styles
  • Specific project conventions
  • Domain-specific knowledge

docs.title: MCP Tool Integration
docs.text:
When MCP servers are connected, additional tools become available:

[tool_start] mcp_server_tool_name
[tool_end] success

docs.title: Skills Integration
docs.text:
Skills extend agent capabilities:

"Extract text from document.pdf"

[tool_start] read_file: ~/.kuse-cowork/skills/pdf/SKILL.md
[tool_end] Loaded skill instructions
[tool_start] docker_run: python /skills/pdf/extract.py /workspace/document.pdf
[tool_end] Extracted text content

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
Current limitations of the agent system:

  • Max turns: 50 turns per task (configurable)
  • Context window: Limited by model's context length
  • File size: Large files are truncated
  • Network: Cannot make arbitrary HTTP requests
  • Interactive: Cannot handle interactive prompts

docs.text:

  • Skills System - Extend agent capabilities
  • MCP Protocol - Connect external tools

docs.title: MCP Protocol
docs.text: MCP (Model Context Protocol) allows Kuse Cowork to connect to external tool providers, extending the agent's capabilities.

docs.title: What is MCP?
docs.text:
MCP is a protocol that enables AI agents to discover and use tools from external servers. It provides:

  • Dynamic Tool Discovery: Servers advertise available tools
  • Standardized Interface: Common format for tool invocation
  • Secure Authentication: OAuth and token-based auth

docs.title: Adding a Server
docs.text:
1. Open Settings → MCP
  2. Click Add Server
  3. Enter server details:
{
  "name": "my-mcp-server",
  "url": "http://localhost:3000",
  "transport": "http"
}
  1. Configure authentication if required
  2. Click Connect

docs.title: Server Configuration
docs.text: Field Description Required name Display name Yes url Server URL Yes transport http or stdio Yes auth Authentication config No

docs.title: No Authentication
docs.text:
{
  "name": "local-server",
  "url": "http://localhost:3000",
  "transport": "http"
}

docs.title: Bearer Token
docs.text:
{
  "name": "api-server",
  "url": "https://api.example.com",
  "transport": "http",
  "auth": {
    "type": "bearer",
    "token": "your-api-token"
  }
}

docs.title: OAuth
docs.text:
{
  "name": "oauth-server",
  "url": "https://service.example.com",
  "transport": "http",
  "auth": {
    "type": "oauth",
    "clientId": "your-client-id",
    "authUrl": "https://service.example.com/oauth/authorize",
    "tokenUrl": "https://service.example.com/oauth/token"
  }
}

docs.title: Using MCP Tools
docs.text: Once connected, MCP tools appear automatically in the agent's tool list.

docs.title: Tool Naming
docs.text:
MCP tools are prefixed with server identifier:

mcp_<server_id>_<tool_name>

Example: 

mcp_github_create_issue
mcp_slack_send_message
mcp_database_query

docs.title: Tool Discovery
docs.text:
The agent automatically discovers tools when:

  1. Server connects successfully
  2. Server status changes to "Connected"
  3. Tools are listed in the agent's context

docs.title: Tool Invocation
docs.text:
{
  "name": "mcp_github_create_issue",
  "input": {
    "repo": "owner/repo",
    "title": "Bug Report",
    "body": "Description of the bug"
  }
}

docs.title: Status Indicators
docs.text: Status Description 🟢 Connected Server is responsive 🟡 Connecting Connection in progress 🔴 Disconnected Server unreachable ⚠️ Error Configuration issue

docs.title: Connection Management
docs.text:
• Reconnect: Retry failed connections
  • Disconnect: Temporarily disable server
  • Remove: Delete server configuration

docs.title: Server Requirements
docs.text:
MCP servers must implement:

  1. Tool List Endpoint: Return available tools
  2. Tool Call Endpoint: Execute tool invocations
  3. Health Check: Confirm server status

docs.title: Example Server (Python)
docs.text:
from fastapi import FastAPI
from pydantic import BaseModel

app = FastAPI()

# Tool definitions
TOOLS = [
    {
        "name": "hello_world",
        "description": "Returns a greeting",
        "inputSchema": {
            "type": "object",
            "properties": {
                "name": {"type": "string"}
            },
            "required": ["name"]
        }
    }
]

@app.get("/tools")
def list_tools():
    return {"tools": TOOLS}

@app.post("/tools/call")
def call_tool(request: dict):
    tool_name = request["name"]
    args = request["arguments"]

    if tool_name == "hello_world":
        return {"result": f"Hello, {args['name']}!"}

    return {"error": f"Unknown tool: {tool_name}"}

@app.get("/health")
def health():
    return {"status": "ok"}

docs.title: Example Server (Node.js)
docs.text:
const express = require('express');
const app = express();
app.use(express.json());

const tools = [
  {
    name: 'calculate',
    description: 'Performs calculations',
    inputSchema: {
      type: 'object',
      properties: {
        expression: { type: 'string' }
      },
      required: ['expression']
    }
  }
];

app.get('/tools', (req, res) => {
  res.json({ tools });
});

app.post('/tools/call', (req, res) => {
  const { name, arguments: args } = req.body;

  if (name === 'calculate') {
    const result = eval(args.expression); // Use safe-eval in production!
    return res.json({ result: result.toString() });
  }

  res.status(404).json({ error: `Unknown tool: ${name}` });
});

app.get('/health', (req, res) => {
  res.json({ status: 'ok' });
});

app.listen(3000);

docs.title: External API Integration
docs.text:
Connect to external services:

  • GitHub: Create issues, PRs, manage repos
  • Slack: Send messages, manage channels
  • Jira: Create tickets, update status
  • Databases: Query and modify data

docs.title: Custom Tooling
docs.text:
Build project-specific tools:

  • Deployment: Trigger CI/CD pipelines
  • Monitoring: Check service health
  • Documentation: Generate docs from code

docs.title: Enterprise Integration
docs.text:
Connect to internal services:

  • Internal APIs: Access proprietary systems
  • Data Sources: Query internal databases
  • Automation: Trigger internal workflows

docs.title: Network Security
docs.text:
Local Servers Only

Only connect to trusted MCP servers. Malicious servers can execute arbitrary actions.

docs.title: Token Management
docs.text:
• Store tokens securely
  • Use short-lived tokens when possible
  • Rotate tokens regularly

docs.title: OAuth Security
docs.text:
• Verify OAuth redirect URLs
  • Use PKCE for public clients
  • Validate token scopes

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Server not connecting
  1. Verify URL is correct
  2. Check server is running
  3. Confirm network accessibility
  4. Review authentication config
Tools not appearing
  1. Check server status is "Connected"
  2. Verify /tools endpoint returns valid response
  3. Restart Kuse Cowork
Tool calls failing
  1. Check tool input matches schema
  2. Review server logs
  3. Verify authentication is valid
OAuth flow not completing
  1. Check redirect URL configuration
  2. Verify client ID/secret
  3. Confirm token endpoint is accessible

docs.title: Configuration Storage
docs.text:
MCP server configurations are stored in:

~/.kuse-cowork/settings.db

Column Type Description id TEXT Unique identifier name TEXT Display name config JSON Server configuration status TEXT Connection status

docs.title: Features Overview
docs.text: Kuse Cowork is a comprehensive AI agent framework designed for developers who need powerful automation with complete privacy control.

docs.title: Multi-Provider AI Support
docs.text:
Connect to any major AI provider or run models locally:

  • Official APIs: Anthropic Claude, OpenAI GPT, Google Gemini, Minimax
  • Local Inference: Ollama, LocalAI, vLLM, Text Generation Inference
  • Aggregators: OpenRouter, Together AI, Groq, SiliconFlow, DeepSeek
  • Custom Endpoints: Any OpenAI-compatible API

Learn more →

docs.title: Autonomous Agent System
docs.text:
An intelligent agent that can plan and execute complex tasks:

  • Automatic Planning: Analyzes tasks and creates step-by-step plans
  • Tool Orchestration: Uses the right tools for each step
  • Progress Tracking: Real-time visibility into execution status
  • Context Awareness: Maintains context across conversation turns

Learn more →

docs.title: Comprehensive Tool Suite
docs.text:
Built-in tools for common development tasks:

Tool Description read_file Read file contents write_file Create or overwrite files edit_file Make targeted edits bash Execute shell commands glob Find files by pattern grep Search file contents list_dir List directory contents docker_run Run containers

Learn more →

docs.title: Extensible Skills System
docs.text:
Extend agent capabilities with skills:

  • Built-in Skills: PDF, DOCX, XLSX, PPTX processing
  • Custom Skills: Create your own skills with simple YAML/Markdown
  • Auto-mounting: Skills available in Docker containers at /skills
  • Script Execution: Python, Node.js, and other runtime support

Learn more →

docs.title: MCP Protocol Support
docs.text:
Connect external tools and services:

  • Dynamic Tools: Discover and use tools from MCP servers
  • OAuth Support: Secure authentication with external services
  • Real-time Status: Monitor server connections
  • Error Handling: Graceful fallbacks and retries

Learn more →

docs.title: Local-First Architecture
docs.text:
All data stays on your machine:

  • SQLite for local storage
  • API keys stored locally only
  • No telemetry or analytics
  • Works offline with local models

docs.title: Docker Isolation
docs.text:
Commands execute in isolated containers:

  • Sandboxed execution environment
  • Controlled filesystem access
  • Resource limits and timeouts
  • Clean container per execution

docs.title: BYOK (Bring Your Own Key)
docs.text:
Complete control over your AI access:

  • Use your own API keys
  • Connect to your own endpoints
  • Pay only for what you use
  • Switch providers anytime

docs.title: Chat Interface
docs.text:
Simple conversational interaction:

  • Markdown Rendering: Rich text formatting
  • Code Highlighting: Syntax highlighting for 100+ languages
  • Tool Toggle: Enable/disable tool access
  • Message History: Persistent conversation history

docs.title: Task Management
docs.text:
Organize complex work:

  • Task Creation: Describe what you want to accomplish
  • Project Context: Associate tasks with project folders
  • Progress Panel: Real-time execution status
  • History: Review past tasks and results

docs.title: Settings Panel
docs.text:
Easy configuration:

  • Provider Selection: Visual model picker
  • Connection Testing: Verify API connectivity
  • MCP Management: Add and manage MCP servers
  • Docker Status: Monitor container connectivity

docs.title: Project Integration
docs.text:
Work with your existing projects:

  • Folder Selection: Pick any directory as workspace
  • Codebase Awareness: Agent understands project structure
  • File Operations: Read, write, and edit project files
  • Build Integration: Run build commands and tests

docs.title: IDE-like Features
docs.text:
Developer-focused functionality:

  • Code Search: Find code with glob and grep
  • File Navigation: Browse project structure
  • Diff View: See changes before applying
  • Error Detection: Parse and explain errors

docs.title: Streaming Responses
docs.text:
Real-time output:

  • Token Streaming: See responses as they generate
  • Progress Events: Track tool execution
  • Incremental Updates: UI updates in real-time

docs.title: Efficient Execution
docs.text:
Optimized for developer workflows:

  • Parallel Tool Calls: Execute multiple tools simultaneously
  • Context Caching: Reuse relevant context
  • Smart Truncation: Handle large files gracefully

docs.title: Cross-Platform
docs.text:
Runs on all major operating systems:

  • macOS (Intel and Apple Silicon)
  • Windows 10/11
  • Linux (Ubuntu, Fedora, Arch)

docs.title: Native Performance
docs.text:
Built with Rust and Tauri:

  • Small Binary: ~20MB download size
  • Low Memory: Efficient resource usage
  • Fast Startup: Opens in seconds
  • Native Look: Follows system theme

1. Open Settings (⚙️)
  2. Select provider from the dropdown
  3. Enter API key (if required)
  4. Select model
  5. Click "Test Connection"

docs.title: API Key Storage
docs.text:
API keys are stored in:

~/.kuse-cowork/settings.db

Keys are:

  • Stored locally only
  • Never sent to third parties
  • Associated with specific providers

docs.title: Per-Provider Keys
docs.text:
You can configure different API keys for each provider:

{
  "providerKeys": {
    "anthropic": "sk-ant-...",
    "openai": "sk-...",
    "openrouter": "sk-or-..."
  }
}

When switching models, the appropriate key is automatically selected.

docs.title: OpenAI-Compatible Endpoints
docs.text:
Connect to any OpenAI-compatible API:

  1. Select "Custom Service" as provider
  2. Enter base URL
  3. Configure authentication
  4. Enter model ID

Example: LM Studio

Base URL: http://localhost:1234/v1
Auth: None
Model: local-model

docs.title: Enterprise Deployments
docs.text:
For Azure OpenAI or self-hosted deployments:

Base URL: https://your-deployment.openai.azure.com
Auth: Bearer token
Model: your-deployment-name

docs.title: Reasoning Models
docs.text: Some models have special requirements:

docs.title: Temperature Restrictions
docs.text:
The following models don't support custom temperature:

  • OpenAI: o1-*, o3-*, gpt-5*
  • DeepSeek: deepseek-reasoner

Temperature is automatically ignored for these models.

docs.title: Extended Thinking
docs.text:
Some models support extended thinking/reasoning:

  • Gemini 3: Uses thoughtSignature for function calling
  • Claude: Uses extended thinking mode

docs.title: Choosing a Provider
docs.text: Use Case Recommended Provider General coding Claude Sonnet Complex reasoning Claude Opus or GPT-5 Fast iteration Groq or Ollama Privacy-focused Local models (Ollama) Cost optimization OpenRouter Chinese content Qwen or DeepSeek

docs.title: Cost Management
docs.text:
• Use smaller models for simple tasks
  • Use local models for development/testing
  • Monitor usage through provider dashboards

docs.title: Performance Tips
docs.text:
• Groq offers fastest cloud inference
  • Ollama is fastest for local (if you have GPU)
  • Use streaming for better UX

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Connection test fails
  1. Verify API key is correct
  2. Check base URL format
  3. Ensure network connectivity
  4. Check provider status page
Model not found
  1. Verify model ID spelling
  2. Check if model is available in your plan
  3. For Ollama, ensure model is pulled
Rate limit errors
  1. Reduce request frequency
  2. Upgrade provider plan
  3. Use multiple provider keys

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Agent System - Learn how the agent uses models
  • Tools - Understand tool execution
  • Configuration - Detailed settings

docs.title: Skills System
docs.text: Skills extend the agent's capabilities with specialized processing for specific file types and tasks.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Skills are modular extensions that teach the agent how to handle specific tasks:

  • Document Processing: PDF, DOCX, XLSX, PPTX
  • Data Transformation: Format conversion, extraction
  • Custom Workflows: Project-specific automation

docs.title: Built-in Skills
docs.text: Kuse Cowork includes several built-in skills:

docs.title: PDF Processing
docs.text:
Extract text and analyze PDF documents.

Location: ~/.kuse-cowork/skills/pdf/

Capabilities: - Extract text content - Parse tables - Handle multi-page documents

Usage: 

"Extract the text from report.pdf"

docs.title: DOCX Processing
docs.text:
Work with Microsoft Word documents.

Location: ~/.kuse-cowork/skills/docx/

Capabilities: - Extract text content - Preserve formatting info - Handle embedded images (metadata)

Usage: 

"Summarize the content of proposal.docx"

docs.title: XLSX Processing
docs.text:
Process Excel spreadsheets.

Location: ~/.kuse-cowork/skills/xlsx/

Capabilities: - Read cell data - Parse multiple sheets - Handle formulas (values)

Usage: 

"Analyze the data in sales.xlsx"

docs.title: PPTX Processing
docs.text:
Handle PowerPoint presentations.

Location: ~/.kuse-cowork/skills/pptx/

Capabilities: - Extract slide text - Read speaker notes - Parse slide structure

Usage: 

"Create an outline from presentation.pptx"

docs.title: Skill Structure
docs.text:
Each skill follows a standard structure:

~/.kuse-cowork/skills/
└── my-skill/
    ├── SKILL.md        # Skill definition and instructions
    ├── forms.md        # Optional: Input forms
    ├── reference.md    # Optional: Additional documentation
    └── scripts/        # Optional: Executable scripts
        ├── process.py
        └── convert.sh

docs.title: SKILL.md Format
docs.text:
The main skill definition file:

# My Custom Skill

A brief description of what this skill does.

## Trigger

Keywords or patterns that activate this skill:
- "convert to X"
- "process Y file"

## Instructions

When activated, follow these steps:

1. Read the input file using read_file
2. Run the processing script: `python /skills/my-skill/scripts/process.py`
3. Return the output to the user

## Parameters

- **input_file**: Path to the file to process
- **output_format**: Desired output format

## Examples

### Example 1: Basic Usage
Input: "Process document.pdf"
Action: Run extraction script and return text

### Example 2: With Options
Input: "Process document.pdf as markdown"
Action: Run extraction with markdown formatting

docs.title: Step 1: Create Skill Directory
docs.text: mkdir -p ~/.kuse-cowork/skills/my-skill/scripts

docs.title: Step 2: Write SKILL.md
docs.text:
# CSV to JSON Converter

Converts CSV files to JSON format.

## Trigger
- "convert csv to json"
- "csv to json"

## Instructions

1. Read the CSV file path from user input
2. Run: `python /skills/csv-converter/scripts/convert.py <input_file>`
3. Return the JSON output

## Parameters
- **input_file**: Path to the CSV file
- **pretty**: Whether to format output (default: true)

docs.title: Step 3: Create Scripts
docs.text:
scripts/convert.py
#!/usr/bin/env python3
import csv
import json
import sys

def convert(input_file):
    with open(input_file, 'r') as f:
        reader = csv.DictReader(f)
        data = list(reader)
    return json.dumps(data, indent=2)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    if len(sys.argv) < 2:
        print("Usage: convert.py <input_file>")
        sys.exit(1)
    print(convert(sys.argv[1]))

docs.title: Step 4: Test the Skill
docs.text:
User: "Convert data.csv to JSON"

Agent:
[Reading skill definition]
[Running: python /skills/csv-converter/scripts/convert.py /workspace/data.csv]
[Returning JSON output]

docs.title: Skill Discovery
docs.text:
The agent discovers skills through:

  1. System Prompt: Skills directory is mentioned in the system prompt
  2. Automatic Mounting: Skills are mounted at /skills in Docker
  3. SKILL.md Parsing: Agent reads skill definitions when needed

docs.title: Skill Loading Flow
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[User Request] --> B{Matches Skill Trigger?}
    B -->|Yes| C[Read SKILL.md]
    C --> D[Follow Instructions]
    D --> E[Execute Scripts via Docker]
    E --> F[Return Results]
    B -->|No| G[Standard Processing]

docs.title: Dependencies
docs.text:
Skills can specify required packages:

## Dependencies

Python packages (installed in container):
- pandas
- openpyxl

Install command:
`pip install pandas openpyxl`

docs.title: Multi-Step Processing
docs.text:
Skills can define complex workflows:

## Instructions

### Step 1: Extract
Run: `python /skills/doc-processor/scripts/extract.py <input>`

### Step 2: Transform
Run: `python /skills/doc-processor/scripts/transform.py <extracted_data>`

### Step 3: Format
Run: `python /skills/doc-processor/scripts/format.py <transformed_data>`

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
Skills can specify error handling:

## Error Handling

If extraction fails:
1. Check file format is supported
2. Try alternative extraction method
3. Report specific error to user

docs.title: Design Guidelines
docs.text:
Single Responsibility

Each skill should do one thing well.

Clear Triggers

Define specific, unambiguous trigger phrases.

Detailed Instructions

Provide step-by-step instructions the agent can follow.

docs.title: Script Guidelines
docs.text:
Standalone Scripts

Scripts should work independently with clear input/output.

Error Messages

Provide helpful error messages for common issues.

Standard I/O

Use stdin/stdout for data flow when possible.

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
Include Examples

Show concrete examples of skill usage.

Document Parameters

List all parameters with descriptions and defaults.

docs.title: Default Skills
docs.text:
~/.kuse-cowork/skills/
├── pdf/
├── docx/
├── xlsx/
└── pptx/

docs.title: Custom Skills
docs.text:
Add custom skills in the same directory:

~/.kuse-cowork/skills/
├── pdf/
├── docx/
├── xlsx/
├── pptx/
├── my-custom-skill/
└── another-skill/

docs.title: Docker Access
docs.text:
All skills are mounted at /skills in containers:

# In Docker container
ls /skills/
# Output: pdf docx xlsx pptx my-custom-skill another-skill

docs.title: Export a Skill
docs.text:
cd ~/.kuse-cowork/skills
zip -r my-skill.zip my-skill/

docs.title: Import a Skill
docs.text:
cd ~/.kuse-cowork/skills
unzip my-skill.zip

docs.title: Community Skills
docs.text: Future versions may support: - Skill marketplace - One-click installation - Version management

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Skill not detected
  1. Verify SKILL.md exists in skill directory
  2. Check skill directory is in ~/.kuse-cowork/skills/
  3. Restart Kuse Cowork
Script fails to run
  1. Check script has execute permissions
  2. Verify shebang line (#!/usr/bin/env python3)
  3. Test script manually in Docker
Dependencies not found
  1. Install deps in Docker: docker_run pip install <package>
  2. Add installation to script
  3. Use custom Docker image with deps

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Tools Reference - Built-in tools
  • Agent System - How skills are used
  • Development Guide - Contributing skills

docs.title: Tools Reference
docs.text: Tools are the building blocks that allow the Kuse Cowork agent to interact with your system and codebase.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The agent can use tools to:

  • Read and modify files
  • Execute shell commands
  • Search and navigate codebases
  • Run code in isolated containers

docs.title: read_file
docs.text:
Read the contents of a file.

Parameters:

Parameter Type Required Description path string Yes Path to the file

Example:

{
  "name": "read_file",
  "input": {
    "path": "src/components/Button.tsx"
  }
}

Features:

  • Supports ~ expansion for home directory
  • Handles large files with truncation
  • Returns line numbers for easy reference

docs.title: write_file
docs.text:
Create or overwrite a file.

Parameters:

Parameter Type Required Description path string Yes Path to the file content string Yes Content to write

Example:

{
  "name": "write_file",
  "input": {
    "path": "src/utils/helpers.ts",
    "content": "export function helper() {\n  return true;\n}"
  }
}

Features:

  • Creates parent directories if needed
  • Overwrites existing files
  • Supports any text content

docs.title: edit_file
docs.text:
Make targeted edits to an existing file.

Parameters:

Parameter Type Required Description path string Yes Path to the file old_content string Yes Text to find and replace new_content string Yes Replacement text

Example:

{
  "name": "edit_file",
  "input": {
    "path": "src/config.ts",
    "old_content": "const DEBUG = false;",
    "new_content": "const DEBUG = true;"
  }
}

Features:

  • Precise search-and-replace
  • Preserves file formatting
  • Supports multi-line edits
  • Reports if match not found

docs.title: list_dir
docs.text:
List contents of a directory.

Parameters:

Parameter Type Required Description path string Yes Directory path

Example:

{
  "name": "list_dir",
  "input": {
    "path": "src/components"
  }
}

Output:

Button.tsx
Card.tsx
Modal/
  index.tsx
  styles.css

docs.title: glob
docs.text:
Find files matching a pattern.

Parameters:

Parameter Type Required Description pattern string Yes Glob pattern path string No Base directory (default: project root)

Example:

{
  "name": "glob",
  "input": {
    "pattern": "**/*.test.ts",
    "path": "src"
  }
}

Pattern Examples:

Pattern Matches *.ts TypeScript files in current dir **/*.ts All TypeScript files recursively src/**/*.{ts,tsx} TS/TSX files in src !**/node_modules/** Exclude node_modules

docs.title: grep
docs.text:
Search file contents.

Parameters:

Parameter Type Required Description pattern string Yes Regex pattern to search path string No Directory or file to search include string No File pattern to include

Example:

{
  "name": "grep",
  "input": {
    "pattern": "function handleSubmit",
    "path": "src",
    "include": "*.tsx"
  }
}

Output:

src/components/Form.tsx:45: function handleSubmit(event) {
src/components/Login.tsx:23: function handleSubmit() {

docs.title: bash
docs.text:
Execute shell commands.

Parameters:

Parameter Type Required Description command string Yes Command to execute cwd string No Working directory

Example:

{
  "name": "bash",
  "input": {
    "command": "npm test -- --coverage",
    "cwd": "/workspace"
  }
}

Features:

  • Runs in project context
  • Captures stdout and stderr
  • Has timeout protection
  • Returns exit code

Security

Commands run on your local system. Be cautious with destructive commands.

docs.title: docker_run
docs.text:
Run commands in Docker containers.

Parameters:

Parameter Type Required Description command string Yes Command to run image string No Docker image (default: python:3.11-alpine) workdir string No Working directory (default: /workspace)

Example:

{
  "name": "docker_run",
  "input": {
    "command": "python script.py",
    "image": "python:3.11-alpine",
    "workdir": "/workspace"
  }
}

Available Images:

Image Use Case python:3.11-alpine Python scripts (default) node:20 Node.js scripts ubuntu:latest General purpose rust:alpine Rust compilation

Mount Points:

Host Path Container Path Access Project folder /workspace Read/Write Skills directory /skills Read-only

docs.title: docker_list
docs.text:
List running Docker containers.

Parameters: None

Example:

{
  "name": "docker_list",
  "input": {}
}

docs.title: docker_images
docs.text:
List available Docker images.

Parameters: None

Example:

{
  "name": "docker_images",
  "input": {}
}

docs.title: MCP Tools
docs.text:
When MCP servers are connected, additional tools become available dynamically:

{
  "name": "mcp_servername_toolname",
  "input": {
    "param1": "value1"
  }
}

See MCP Protocol for details.

docs.title: Tool Execution Flow
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant Agent
    participant ToolExecutor
    participant Docker
    participant FileSystem

    Agent->>ToolExecutor: Execute tool
    alt File operation
        ToolExecutor->>FileSystem: Read/Write file
        FileSystem-->>ToolExecutor: Result
    else Docker command
        ToolExecutor->>Docker: Create container
        Docker->>Docker: Execute command
        Docker-->>ToolExecutor: Output
        ToolExecutor->>Docker: Remove container
    end
    ToolExecutor-->>Agent: Tool result

docs.title: Common Errors
docs.text: Error Cause Solution File not found Invalid path Check path with list_dir or glob Permission denied Access restricted Check file permissions Container failed Docker issue Verify Docker is running Match not found Edit target missing Verify exact match exists Timeout Long-running command Break into smaller operations

docs.title: Error Response Format
docs.text:
{
  "tool_use_id": "tool_123",
  "content": "Error: File not found: /path/to/file.txt",
  "is_error": true
}

docs.title: File Operations
docs.text:
Read Before Edit

Always read a file before editing to understand its current state.

Use Exact Matches

For edit_file, use the exact text including whitespace.

Prefer edit_file

Use edit_file for modifications, write_file only for new files.

docs.title: Search Operations
docs.text:
Start Broad

Use glob to find files, then grep to search within them.

Use Specific Patterns

More specific patterns are faster and produce fewer results.

docs.title: Command Execution
docs.text:
Prefer Docker

Use docker_run for risky or experimental commands.

Check Exit Codes

Tool results include exit codes for command success/failure.

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
Batch Operations

Combine related operations to reduce API calls.

Use Working Directory

Set cwd to avoid long absolute paths.

docs.title: Allowed Tools
docs.text:
Tools can be restricted per task:

AgentConfig {
    allowed_tools: vec![
        "read_file".to_string(),
        "glob".to_string(),
        "grep".to_string(),
    ],
}

docs.title: Docker Settings
docs.text:
Container resource limits:

  • Memory: Default unlimited
  • CPU: Default unlimited
  • Timeout: 5 minutes per command
  • Network: Host network by default

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Skills System - Extend tool capabilities
  • Agent System - How tools are orchestrated
  • MCP Protocol - Add external tools

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: This guide covers all configuration options in Kuse Cowork.

docs.title: Settings Overview
docs.text: Access settings by clicking the gear icon (⚙️) in the top-right corner of the application.

docs.title: Provider Selection
docs.text:
Kuse Cowork supports multiple AI providers:

Provider Type API Key Required Anthropic Official API Yes OpenAI Official API Yes Google Official API Yes Minimax Official API Yes DeepSeek Official API Yes Ollama Local No LocalAI Local No OpenRouter Aggregator Yes Together AI Aggregator Yes Groq Aggregator Yes SiliconFlow Aggregator Yes

docs.title: API Key Management
docs.text:
API keys are stored locally in an encrypted SQLite database. Keys are never sent to any server other than the respective AI provider.

~/.kuse-cowork/settings.db

API Key Safety

  • Keys are stored locally only
  • No telemetry or analytics
  • Keys are passed directly to provider APIs

docs.title: Model Selection
docs.text:
Each provider offers multiple models:

AnthropicOpenAILocal (Ollama) Model Description claude-opus-4-5-20251101 Most capable claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929 Balanced (recommended) Model Description gpt-5 Latest flagship gpt-5-mini Fast and efficient gpt-4o Multimodal Model Description llama3.3:latest Meta's latest open source qwen2.5:latest Good for Chinese codellama:latest Code-specialized deepseek-r1:latest Strong reasoning

docs.title: Custom Endpoints
docs.text:
For self-hosted or enterprise deployments:

  1. Select "Custom Service" as provider
  2. Enter your base URL (e.g., http://localhost:8000)
  3. Configure authentication if needed
  4. Enter your model ID

docs.title: Max Tokens
docs.text:
Controls the maximum length of AI responses:

  • Default: 4096 tokens
  • Range: 256 - 128000 tokens
  • Recommendation: 4096 for chat, 8192+ for code generation

docs.title: Temperature
docs.text:
Controls response randomness:

  • 0.0: Deterministic, focused
  • 0.7: Balanced (default)
  • 1.0: Creative, varied

Reasoning Models

GPT-5, o1, and o3 models don't support custom temperature.

docs.title: Project Folder
docs.text:
Set the working directory for tasks:

  1. Click "Select Folder" in task creation
  2. Browse to your project root
  3. The agent will have access to all files in this directory

Docker Mounting

The project folder is mounted at /workspace in Docker containers.

docs.title: Skills Directory
docs.text:
Custom skills are stored in:

~/.kuse-cowork/skills/

See Skills Guide for creating custom skills.

docs.title: Container Settings
docs.text:
Kuse Cowork uses Docker for safe command execution:

Setting Value Default Image python:3.11-alpine Available Images ubuntu:latest, node:20, rust:alpine Workspace Mount /workspace Skills Mount /skills (read-only)

docs.title: Verifying Docker
docs.text:
Check Docker status in Settings. If disconnected:

  1. Ensure Docker Desktop is running
  2. Check Docker socket permissions
  3. Restart Kuse Cowork

docs.title: Adding MCP Servers
docs.text:
1. Go to Settings → MCP
  2. Click "Add Server"
  3. Enter server configuration:
{
  "name": "my-mcp-server",
  "url": "http://localhost:3000",
  "auth": {
    "type": "bearer",
    "token": "your-token"
  }
}

docs.title: OAuth MCP Servers
docs.text:
For OAuth-authenticated MCP servers:

  1. Click "Connect with OAuth"
  2. Complete authentication in browser
  3. Token is stored locally

docs.title: Data Storage
docs.text:
All data is stored locally:

Data Location Settings ~/.kuse-cowork/settings.db Conversations ~/.kuse-cowork/settings.db Tasks ~/.kuse-cowork/settings.db Skills ~/.kuse-cowork/skills/

docs.title: Backup
docs.text:
To backup your data:

cp -r ~/.kuse-cowork ~/.kuse-cowork-backup

docs.title: Reset
docs.text:
To reset all settings:

rm -rf ~/.kuse-cowork

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
For advanced configuration, environment variables can be used:

Variable Description KUSE_DATA_DIR Override data directory KUSE_LOG_LEVEL Set log level (debug, info, warn, error)

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
Settings can also be configured via JSON:

~/.kuse-cowork/config.json
{
  "defaultProvider": "anthropic",
  "defaultModel": "claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929",
  "maxTokens": 4096,
  "temperature": 0.7,
  "dockerEnabled": true
}

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• AI Providers - Detailed provider documentation
  • Skills - Create custom skills
  • MCP Protocol - Connect external tools

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide covers how to install Kuse Cowork on your system.

docs.title: Minimum Requirements
docs.text: Component Requirement OS macOS 10.15+, Windows 10+, Linux (Ubuntu 20.04+) RAM 4 GB Disk 500 MB free space Docker Docker Desktop or Docker Engine

docs.title: Recommended Requirements
docs.text: Component Requirement RAM 8 GB+ (16 GB for local models) Disk 2 GB+ (more for local models) GPU NVIDIA GPU with CUDA (for local models)

docs.title: Method 1: Download Pre-built Binaries
docs.text:
The easiest way to install Kuse Cowork is to download pre-built binaries from GitHub Releases.

  1. Go to GitHub Releases
  2. Download the appropriate file for your platform:
  3. macOS: kuse-cowork_x.x.x_aarch64.dmg (Apple Silicon) or kuse-cowork_x.x.x_x64.dmg (Intel)
  4. Windows: kuse-cowork_x.x.x_x64-setup.exe
  5. Linux: kuse-cowork_x.x.x_amd64.deb or kuse-cowork_x.x.x_amd64.AppImage
  6. Install the application

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before building from source, ensure you have:

macOSWindowsLinux 
# Install Homebrew if not installed
/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"

# Install dependencies
brew install node pnpm rust

# Install Tauri CLI
cargo install tauri-cli
  1. Install Node.js (v18+)
  2. Install pnpm: npm install -g pnpm
  3. Install Rust
  4. Install Visual Studio Build Tools
  5. Install Tauri CLI: cargo install tauri-cli
# Install dependencies (Ubuntu/Debian)
sudo apt update
sudo apt install -y libwebkit2gtk-4.1-dev build-essential curl wget libssl-dev libgtk-3-dev libayatana-appindicator3-dev librsvg2-dev

# Install Node.js
curl -fsSL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_20.x | sudo -E bash -
sudo apt install -y nodejs

# Install pnpm
npm install -g pnpm

# Install Rust
curl --proto '=https' --tlsv1.2 -sSf https://sh.rustup.rs | sh

# Install Tauri CLI
cargo install tauri-cli

docs.title: Build Steps
docs.text:
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/kuse-ai/kuse_cowork.git
cd kuse_cowork

# Install dependencies
pnpm install

# Development mode
pnpm tauri dev

# Build for production
pnpm tauri build

The built application will be in src-tauri/target/release/bundle/.

docs.title: Docker Setup
docs.text:
Kuse Cowork uses Docker for secure command execution. Make sure Docker is installed and running:

macOSWindowsLinux
  1. Download and install Docker Desktop for Mac
  2. Start Docker Desktop
  3. Verify installation: docker run hello-world
  1. Download and install Docker Desktop for Windows
  2. Enable WSL 2 backend (recommended)
  3. Start Docker Desktop
  4. Verify installation: docker run hello-world
# Install Docker Engine
curl -fsSL https://get.docker.com -o get-docker.sh
sudo sh get-docker.sh

# Add user to docker group
sudo usermod -aG docker $USER
newgrp docker

# Verify installation
docker run hello-world

docs.title: Verifying Installation
docs.text:
After installation, launch Kuse Cowork and verify:

  1. The application opens without errors
  2. Docker status shows "Connected" in settings
  3. You can configure at least one AI provider

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
Application won't start on macOS

If you see "App is damaged and can't be opened", run: 

xattr -cr /Applications/Kuse\ Cowork.app

Docker connection failed
  1. Ensure Docker Desktop is running
  2. Check Docker socket permissions (Linux): 
    sudo chmod 666 /var/run/docker.sock
  3. Restart Kuse Cowork
Build fails on Windows

Ensure Visual Studio Build Tools are installed with "C++ build tools" workload.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Quick Start Guide - Get started with your first task
  • Configuration - Configure API keys and settings

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: This guide will help you get started with Kuse Cowork in minutes.

docs.title: Step 1: Configure an AI Provider
docs.text:
After launching Kuse Cowork, you need to configure at least one AI provider.

  1. Click the Settings icon (⚙️) in the top-right corner
  2. Select your preferred AI provider:
Anthropic ClaudeOpenAILocal (Ollama)
  1. Get your API key from Anthropic Console
  2. Enter your API key
  3. Select a model (e.g., claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929)
  1. Get your API key from OpenAI Platform
  2. Enter your API key
  3. Select a model (e.g., gpt-4o)
  1. Install Ollama
  2. Pull a model: ollama pull llama3.3:latest
  3. Select "Ollama (Local)" as provider
  4. No API key needed!
  1. Click Test Connection to verify
  2. Close the settings panel

docs.title: Step 2: Start a Chat
docs.text:
The simplest way to use Kuse Cowork is through the Chat interface:

  1. Click on Chat in the sidebar
  2. Type your message and press Enter
  3. The AI will respond with helpful information

Try asking

  • "What can you help me with?"
  • "Explain how to use Docker"
  • "Write a Python script that prints Hello World"

docs.title: Step 3: Create a Task with Agent
docs.text:
For more complex, multi-step tasks, use the Agent feature:

  1. Click on Tasks in the sidebar
  2. Click New Task
  3. Enter a task description:

Example tasks

  • "Create a new React component for a login form"
  • "Find and fix the bug in src/utils.ts"
  • "Add unit tests for the UserService class"
  1. Optionally select a Project Folder to give the agent access to your codebase
  2. Click Start

The agent will:

  1. Analyze your request
  2. Create a step-by-step plan
  3. Execute each step, showing progress in real-time
  4. Use tools like file reading, bash commands, and code editing

docs.title: Step 4: Enable Tools
docs.text:
For enhanced functionality, enable tools in Chat mode:

  1. In the Chat view, toggle Enable Tools on
  2. Now the AI can:
  3. Read and search files in your project
  4. Execute commands (in Docker for safety)
  5. Edit files with your approval

Project Folder Required

Tool-enabled chat requires selecting a project folder first.

docs.title: Code Review
docs.text:
You: Review the code in src/components/Button.tsx and suggest improvements

Agent: I'll analyze the Button component...
[Tool: read_file src/components/Button.tsx]
[Analysis and suggestions appear]

docs.title: Bug Investigation
docs.text:
You: The tests in tests/api.test.ts are failing. Help me debug.

Agent: Let me investigate the failing tests...
[Tool: read_file tests/api.test.ts]
[Tool: bash npm test -- tests/api.test.ts]
[Debugging steps and fixes]

docs.title: Code Generation
docs.text:
You: Create a new API endpoint for user registration in src/routes/

Agent: I'll create a user registration endpoint...
[Tool: read_file src/routes/index.ts]
[Tool: write_file src/routes/auth.ts]
[New file created with registration logic]

docs.title: Chat View
docs.text:
• Message Input: Type your messages here
  • Tool Toggle: Enable/disable tool access
  • Project Selector: Choose the working directory

docs.title: Task View
docs.text:
• Task List: All your tasks in the sidebar
  • Progress Panel: Real-time execution status
  • Plan View: Step-by-step plan with status indicators
  • Tool Output: Results from tool executions

docs.title: Settings
docs.text:
• Provider Selection: Choose AI provider
  • Model Selection: Pick specific models
  • API Configuration: Enter API keys and endpoints
  • Docker Status: Verify container connectivity

docs.title: Tips for Better Results
docs.text:
Be Specific

Instead of "fix the bug", try "fix the TypeError in handleSubmit function in src/Form.tsx"

Provide Context

Select a project folder so the agent can read your actual code.

Use Tool Mode for Actions

Enable tools when you want the AI to actually read files or run commands.

Break Down Large Tasks

For complex projects, create multiple focused tasks rather than one large one.
